children.name: start a1
children.definition: start/stɑːʳt/  bắt đầu
examples: ▪ we can’t start until carol gets here.
i’m starting a new job next week.
▪ have you started that book yet? started reading it
start doing sth
▪ i’ve just started learning german
.▪ it was getting dark so we started looking for a place to stay the night.
start to do sth
▪ halfway through the performance, she started to feel a little faint.
▪ outside, it was starting to rain.

children.name: begin a2
children.definition: begin/bɪˈgɪn/  to start doing something.beginis more formal thanstartand is used especially in written english:bắt đầu
examples: ▪ once the children were quiet, the teacher began.
▪ they began their holiday in italy, and then went on to greece
.begin to do something: bắt đầu để làm gì
▪ more and more people are beginning to do their shopping on-line.
▪ ‘what do you mean?’ she said, beginning to laugh.
begin doing something: bắt đầu làm gì
▪ the audience suddenly began shouting and cheering.

children.name: get down to b2
children.definition: get down to/ˌget ˈdaʊn tuː/  to finally start doing something, especially work, after you have been avoiding doing it or after something has prevented you from doing it: bắt tay
examples: ▪ come on sam - it’s time you got down to some homework.
get down to to doing something: bắt tay chịu làm việc gì
▪ when the summer comes, we must get down to painting the outside of the house.
get down to business: bắt tay vào việc cần làm
▪ ok, can everyone take a seat now, and we’ll get down to business.

children.name: start on x
children.definition: start on/ˈstɑːʳt ɒn/  to start a piece of work that will take a fairly long time: bắt đầu việc gì
examples: ▪ the exam was almost over and i hadn’t even started on question 3.
▪ it was time to start on all those little jobs around the house that he’d been putting off.
▪ we can’t start on the building work until planning permission comes through.

children.name: set about x
children.definition: set about/set to work/get to work/ˈset əbaʊt, ˌset tə ˈwɜːʳk/  to start a long and fairly difficult piece of work, especially in an energetic and determined way: bắt đầu làm việc gì (với thái độ hăng hái, quyết tâm)
examples: ▪ philip set about the task with a great deal of energy and enthusiasm.
▪ why don’t we set to work really early, and try to get it finished in one day?
set about/set to work doingsomething: bắt đầu làm việc gì
▪ if there is a serious problem, it’s far better to admit it and set about tackling it:
set to work to do something: bắt đầu để làm việc gì
▪ workmen had already set to work to clear the fallen trees
set to work on something
▪ once in power, the government set to work on major reforms to the tax system.

children.name: proceed to do sth c2
children.definition: proceed to do something/prəˌsiːd tə ˈduː something/  to start doing something after you have finished doing something else: tiếp tục làm gì
examples: ▪ martin marched into the shop and proceeded to hurl abuse at the girl behind the counter.
▪ after listening carefully to my advice, she proceeded to do the exact opposite!

children.name: settle down to u
children.definition: settle down to/ˌsetl ˈdaʊn tuː/  to start doing something after a delay or interruption that has stopped you giving it your full attention:tiếp tục việc gì (sau khi trì hoãn)
examples: ▪ after lunch the children settled down to finish their science projects.
settle down to to doing something: tiếp tục làm việc gì
▪ it was two o'clock before i could finally settle down to writing the next chapter.

children.name: launch into x
children.definition: launch into to suddenly start a long speech or story, especially if you are criticizing something or giving an entertaining description of something: bắt tay vào việc gì
examples: ▪ annie arrived late and immediately launched into a lengthy description of the terrible traffic on the roads.
▪ at that point the young man stood up and launched into a passionate party-political speech.

children.name: embark on x
children.definition: embark on/upon/ɪmˈbɑːʳk ɒn, əpɒn/  to start a large piece of work or an important activity, especially one that will be difficult or will take a long time:bắt đầu làm việc gì
examples: ▪ in the 1950s china embarked on a massive program of industrialization and mechanization.
▪ after leaving his office job, he embarked upon a highly successful writing career.

children.name: come to u
children.definition: come to/grow to/get to/ˈkʌm tuː, ˈgrəʊ tuː, ˈget tuː/  to gradually start to like, fear, expect etc something over a period of time: dần dần trở nên thích/sợ/hi vọng điều gì
examples: ▪ rowling’s latest book is full of all the magic and excitement that her young readers have come to expect.
▪ at first i thought he was a bit strange, but i grew to like and respect him over the years.
▪ my teacher said that this wasn’t the kind of work that she’d come to expect of me.

children.name: get cracking x
children.definition: get cracking/ˌget ˈkrækɪŋ/  spoken informal to start doing something immediately, because you are in a hurry or there is a lot to do:bắt đầu làm gì ngay lập tức
examples: ▪ come on! - get cracking. i want this whole house clean by the time i get back.
▪ you’d better get cracking if you want to get to the airport by ten.

children.name: to help or encourage sb to start doing sth new
introduce sb to x
children.definition: introduce sb to to make someone start doing something or start enjoying something, by telling them about it or showing it to them: giới thiệu ai tới cái gì
examples: ▪ her father introduced her to rock ‘n’ roll when she was a little girl.
introduce sb to doing sth
▪ it was my sports teacher who first introduced me to skiing.

children.name: initiate sb into x
children.definition: initiate sb into/ɪˈnɪʃieɪt somebody ɪntuː/  to give someone the chance to do something for the first time, especially something unusual or complicated: dạy vỡ lòng cho ai cái gì
examples: ▪ people come to me to be initiated into meditation, as a way of handling stress.
▪ he tried to initiate her into the mysteries of chinese cooking.

children.name: start sb on x
children.definition: start sb on sth to make someone start doing something regularly, especially because it will be good for them: ai bắt đầu làm gì
examples: ▪ most parents start their babies on solid foods when they are about 4 months old.
▪ the doctor said that he wants to start dad on a special low-cholesterol diet.

children.name: to start an activity, job, speech etc by doing the first part of it
start by a1
children.definition: start by/begin by/ˈstɑːʳt baɪ, bɪˈgɪn baɪ/  to do something as the first part of an activity or job: khởi đầu, khởi động
examples: start by/begin by doing sth
▪ there were two interviewers and they began by asking me questions about my last job.
▪ when you’re drawing a face, you should start by trying to imagine the bones underneath.

children.name: start with a1
children.definition: start with/begin with/ˈstɑːʳt wɪð, bɪˈgɪn wɪð/  to think about, introduce, or deal with something as the first part of an activity:bắt đầu khởi đầu với
examples: ▪ if i were you, i’d start with the easy questions
.▪ the lecturer began with a short account of the history of the un.
▪ decorating the place was a huge job, and we started with the kitchen and the hall.

children.name: lead off x
children.definition: lead off to start something such as a meeting or discussion by introducing a subject or speaking first: bắt đầu cuộc họp, cuộc thảo luận
examples: ▪ is there anyone here who would like to lead off the debate?
▪ the chief executive led off by pointing out that a merger was only one option.
lead off with
▪ we asked the sales director to lead off with the latest sales figures.

children.name: kick off with c2
children.definition: kick off with/ˌkɪk ˈɒf wɪð/  informal to do something as the first part of an activity or an event such as a party or a concert:khởi động với
examples: ▪ let’s kick off with an indian meal somewhere, and go on to a club after that.
kick off something with sth
▪ phelps kicked off an outstanding night’s music with a beautifully played mozart symphony.

children.name: to start doing sth again in a better way
start over x
children.definition: start over us to go back to the beginning of something and start again: bắt đầu lại
examples: ▪ if you make a keying error, just delete it and start over.
▪ in 1960 the family fled the island of cuba and, like many others, started over in miami.

children.name: to be the person who starts sth
make the first move x
children.definition: make the first move/meɪk ðə ˌfɜːʳst ˈmuːv/  to be the first one to do something in a situation where both sides feel nervous, embarrassed, angry etc: là người tiên phong
examples: ▪ i’d always been attracted to her, but i was too shy to make the first move.
make the first move to do sth
▪ the employees made the first move to end the strike.

children.name: take the initiative c1
children.definition: take the initiative to be the first one to do something in a situation, especially when you think people are being silly because they are waiting for someone else to do it first: nắm thế chủ động
examples: ▪ everyone was standing around in silence, so i took the initiative and tried to explain why we had come.
▪ the disarmament talks failed because neither side was prepared to risk taking the initiative.

children.name: make a good start c2
children.definition: make a good start/get off to a good start/meɪk ə ˌgʊd ˈstɑːʳt, get ˌɒf tʊ ə ˌgʊd ˈstɑːʳt/
examples: ▪ i haven’t finished all my christmas shopping yet but i’ve made a good start.
▪ chelsea got off to a good start with a victory over southampton on the first day of the season.

children.name: get off to a flying start x
children.definition: get off to a flying start to start doing something very successfully: khởi đầu tốt đẹp
examples: ▪ kate’s got off to a flying start. she was promoted twice in the first six month

children.name: get off to a bad start c2
children.definition: get off to a bad start
examples: ▪ i got off to a bad start at the interview by spilling my coffee all over my notes.
▪ the senator got off to a bad start, twice forgetting the name of the town he was in.

children.name: get off on the wrong foot c2
children.definition: get/start off on the wrong foot to start sth such as a relationship or job and be unsuccessful at the beginning, for example by unintentionally making people upset or angry:bắt đầu một cách không suôn sẻ
examples: what should i wear on my first day? i don’t want to start off on the wrong foot.
john seems to have got off on the wrong foot with angela -- she won’t even speak to him.

children.name: false start x
children.definition: false start/ˌfɔːls ˈstɑːʳt/  an unsuccessful attempt to start doing something such as a piece of work or a plan: bắt đầu xui xẻo
examples: ▪ after a number of false starts, the channel tunnel between england and france finally went ahead in the late 80s.

children.name: start a1
children.definition: start/begina2  to start doing something that you then do regularly.beginis more formal thanstartand is used especially in written english: bắt đầu, khởi đầu
examples: start/begin doing something
▪ i started going to the gym two years ago.
▪ she was only 16 when she began seeing alan.
start/begin to do something
▪ his parents got divorced last year - that’s when he started to take drugs.

children.name: take up b1
children.definition: take up sth/ˌteɪk ˈʌp/  to become interested in a sport or activity, and start to spend time doing it: bắt đầu một sở thích
examples: ▪ when did bryan take up golf?
▪ your pictures are so good - you could take up painting as a profession.

children.name: turn to x
children.definition: turn to/ˈtɜːʳn tuː/  to start doing something dangerous or illegal:
examples: ▪ hal turned to drinking after his wife and kids were killed in a car crash.
▪ research shows that young people without jobs are most likely to turn to crime.

children.name: take to x
children.definition: take to doing something/ˌteɪk tə ˈduːɪŋ something/  to start doing something frequently, especially something that is annoying or worrying:bắt đầu làm gì một cách liên tục (gây phiền phức)
examples: ▪ there’s a big ginger cat that’s taken to coming in our house at night.
▪ my daughter took to spending hours alone in her room, only coming downstairs for meals.

children.name: get into c1
children.definition: get into the habit of/ˌget ɪntə ðə ˈhæbt ɒv/  to start to do something so often that it becomes a habit: bắt đầu một thói quen gì
examples: ▪ i only used to have one or two cigarettes, but then i got into the habit of it.
get into the habit of of doing sth
▪ try to get into the habit of planning your work at the beginning of the day.
